findings.title: FAIR can be stolen using ERC-777 hooks
findings.description: Reentrancy vulnerability in ERC-777 token transfers allows attackers to steal FAIR tokens.

findings.title: BigDiv does not prevent overflow in some cases where it should
findings.description: BigDiv functions fail to prevent overflows in certain scenarios, leading to unexpected failures and potential exploits.

findings.title: Square roots are not calculated accurately for inputs below ~10^30
findings.description: The square rooting logic loses accuracy for small input values due to rounding, potentially causing issues in certain scenarios.

findings.title: Inaccurate calculations in BigDiv
findings.description: BigDiv returns estimates in some cases where it could easily calculate a precise answer.
findings.location: BigDiv contract, functions simpleDiv and bigDiv2x1

findings.title: Unused code in BigDiv functions
findings.description: Some parameters and associated logic can be removed from BigDivâ€™s functions to simplify the code.
findings.location: BigDiv contract, functions bigDiv2x1, bigDiv3x1, and bigDiv3x3

findings.title: Unnecessary Approval event emission in transferFrom
findings.description: The method transferFrom() sends already approved tokens to some address but also emits an Approval event.

findings.title: Insufficient on-chain logic for beneficiary token purchases
findings.description: The buy() function contains unique logic for identifying and processing an investment by the beneficiary, which can be easily circumvented.

findings.title: Non-compliance with ERC-777 standard
findings.description: The contract does not allow per-user revocation of the default operator and does not call the ERC777 tokensToSend and tokensReceived hooks within transfer and transferFrom.

findings.title: Non-compliance with ERC1404 standard
findings.description: The ERC1404 standard is an extension of the ERC20 standard, which has been implemented as a standalone contract but does not contain all of the extra functions required by ERC1404.
